awd_titl_txt: Interrelated Photo and Electrocatalytic Processes for the Reduction of CO2: Controlling Multiproton/Multielectron Events
awd_abstract_narration:
One important approach to remove undesirable CO2 in the atmosphere is to convert it to useful chemicals. This chemistry can be carried out in an electrochemical cell, but there are also recent advances showing that it is possible to do CO2 conversion with light. Thus, one goal is to react CO2 and water with sunlight to generate chemicals that are important both as fuels and as raw materials. Whether this chemistry is carried out electrochemically or photochemically, the reactions require energy. Practical CO2 conversion processes require that the energy input be as small as possible. To that end, catalysts are needed that minimize this energy input while also providing desirable reaction products. Presently, there is only limited understanding of the chemistry needed to build both electrocatalysts and photocatalysts that achieve such efficiency. The Bocarsly research group is advancing the understanding of the fundamental underlying chemistry necessary to develop practical CO2 catalysts. They are using this knowledge to construct new catalysts with improved chemical activity, product selectivity, and energy consumption. This knowledge-based advancement in catalyst design is critical to produce new routes to CO2 utilization that are environmentally responsible and socially beneficial. Dr. Bocarsly is actively engaging in outreach activities related to his research efforts including the education of next generation chemical researchers and K-12 outreach activities carried out under Princeton's Summer Laboratory Learning Program. His activities include a special program to encourage undergraduates in underrepresented groups to consider graduate education in the sciences.


Funding from the National Science Foundation makes possible Dr. Bocarsly's studies at Princeton University on catalysts for electrochemical and photochemical CO2 utilization. Electrocatalytic studies focus on the use of metal alloy systems to address both materials science (i.e. electrode composition) and mechanistic question necessary to understand the reduction of aqueous CO2 to organic oxygenates. Presently, an understanding of the detailed mechanisms that allow the coupling of electron and proton transfer in the reduction of CO2 is being sought. Of particular interest is the reduction of CO2 to form carbon-carbon bonds. Three types of studies are underway: 1) The role of meta-stable surface oxides in the reduction of CO2; 2) The photochemical and electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO using manganese carbonyl complexes as homogeneous catalysts; 3) Mixed metal electrodes as PCET catalysts for the formation of multiple carbon products. Understanding unifying chemical themes that underlie all these systems is transformative in terms of fundamental chemistry and the capability it brings in the areas of new fuel resources and environmental protection. Dr. Bocarsly is heavily involved in the education of next generation electrochemical researchers, who are key to an environmentally sensitive alternate energy future. In addition, Dr. Bocarsly carries out activities in the areas of community outreach and K-12 education through Princeton's Materials Program and Princeton's Summer Laboratory Learning Program. Bocarsly's research program also partners with Princeton's Department of Chemistry Outreach to Underrepresented Minors Program, to bring a diverse selection of the national undergraduate population into Princeton research labs for a 10-week summer research experience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Society's need to both reduce CO2 concentrations in our atmosphere and limit the use of fossil fuels opens up the opportunity to develop new chemistry for the conversion of CO2 to organic products. Most of the products of interest are energetically uphill from CO2 and thus, exquisite control of the needed energy input is require. Further, though the electrochemical conversion of CO2 to C1 products (compounds containing only one carbon atom - like CO2) is somewhat developed, electrochemistry leading to C2 and C2+ products is not generally available. This project is aimed at developing a detailed understanding of the electrochemical mechanisms facilitating the conversion of CO2 to both C1 and C2+ products. 

To this end, we have studied two electrochemical systems. The first, utilizes inorganic complexes in the family, [Mn(diamine)(CO)3X] as electrocatalysts for the conversion of CO2 to CO. The second, system utilizes a heterogeneous electrocatalyst discovered during this work, composed of chromium oxide and gallium oxide on a carbon electrode. This electrocatalyst generates a variety of C2+ products. One exciting aspect of this work has been the synthesis of 1-butanol, which is formed with high efficiency. 

Our initial studies of the [Mn(diamine)(CO)3X] system involved an electrochemical approach. These complexes were reported to be light sensitive, photodecomposing under typical room light conditions, and thus, challenging to study. However, in this work we discovered that if the X moiety was [NCMn(bpy)(CO)3] (where bpy is 2,2'-bipyridine,) the complex became photostable. This bimetallic cyanide bridged manganese complex allowed for the photocatalytic conversion of CO2 to CO using visible light. Based on this finding, we carried out detailed photophysical and mechanistic studies, and compared the photochemical reactivity of the complex to the electrochemical reactivity under conditions where CO2 was converted to CO. In carrying out these studies, we discovered that the original assessment that the [Mn(diamine)(CO)3X] complexes photodecomposed was incorrect. Rather, these complexes are oxygen sensitive, and irradiation in the presence of air initiates a series of reactions that lead to their oxidative degradation. If oxygen is excluded, many of the [Mn(diamine)(CO)3X] complexes can be used to photochemically convert CO2 to CO.

In all cases, we find that the photochemistry of the [Mn(bpy)(CO)3X] complexes leads to the formation of the metal-metal bonded species [bpy(CO)3Mn-Mn)(CO)3bpy], and it is the chemistry of this species that lead to the reduction of CO2 to CO. Based on our observations we have developed a detailed mechanistic model of the process that promotes the conversion of CO2 to CO. This process is critical to the industrial conversion of CO2 to commercially important organic products using syngas chemistry.

The second system under investigation directly forms C2+ products via the electrochemistry of CO2 + H2O. This system, based on a [(Cr2O3)3(Ga2O3)] solid state electrocatalyst was discovered in our labs. Initially, we reported, that the chromium gallium system was electrocatalytic for the synthesis of oxalate. However, through further study of this system we learned that we could suppress the oxalate chemistry, and in so doing activate the electrosynthesis of a variety of C2+ compounds includng: acetic acid, acetone, 3-hydroxybutanal, and 1-butanol.

1-butanol,the major product formed is an important compound both as a fuel, an organic feedstock and as component in various products including paint.The chemistry needed to turn on this industrially important array of products involves addition of a trace amount of nickel metal to the catalyst.

We have spent significant time studying the mechanism(s) that allow the transformation of CO2 to the indicated products, since the further development of this chemistry in terms of both product yields and selectivity, depend on a knowledge of the mechanisms operating and the relationship between those mechanisms and the solid-state nature of the catalyst. 

Concerns about the social impact of climate change and the reliability of fossil based energy and chemical resources makes the chemistry described here of critical importance. We anticipate this work will lead to improved industrial chemistries that have a direct impact on CO2 remediation and the control of greenhouse phenomena. Of equal importance, is the development of a work force that can take the observations and ideas developed in this work and reduce them to practice. This grant has not only developed the chemistry reviewed here, but has trained a significant group of undergraduate and graduate students to carry out future research in this area. Finally, the citizens of our nation and the world need to understand that with sufficient resolve, solutions are available to the ills of climate change, thus, the PI spends significant time in outreach on this topic and the development of industrial ventures aimed at the reduction of atmospheric CO2 concentrations.
